data.title: Why your horse can and can't win the 2019 Kentucky Derby
data.meta_description: Tacitus, By My Standards and Roadster are some of the top contenders for the 2019 Kentucky Derby. Here's why the could win. And why they could lose.
data.text:
Whether it’s the name, the jockey, the pedigree, the speed figures or other factors, horse racing fans have all kinds of ways of making their picks for the Kentucky Derby.

Think you have the winner for Saturday’s race at Churchill Downs? First check out these reasons your horse can and can’t win the race.

Click the name of each horse for more information and to watch video of his last prep race.

Tacitus

Why he can win: He’s won three straight races with improving speed figures each time. Hall of Fame trainer Bill Mott is due to win his first Kentucky Derby, and the gray Juddmonte Farms homebred may give Mott his best shot.

Why he won’t: With only four races under his belt, Tacitus is still a bit green when compared to some of the other top Derby contenders. Given Justify’s Triple Crown run last year, perhaps experience no longer means much on the Derby trail. But it still would be nice to see a couple more races underneath him.

More: Get to know the 20 horses in the field for the 2019 Kentucky Derby

SCRATCHED: Omaha Beach

More: Omaha Beach out of the 2019 Kentucky Derby after entrapped epiglottis

Vekoma

Why he can win: He’s won at Belmont, Aqueduct and Keeneland, so the track doesn’t seem to matter for this one. Trainer George Weaver is an Atherton High School graduate, and a Derby victory would provide a heck of a story at reunions.

Why he won’t: He’s won 3 of 4 career races, so maybe Vekoma’s unorthodox running style is irrelevant. It’s just hard to imagine a horse who runs like THAT winning the Kentucky Derby.

Plus Que Parfait

Why he can win: Maybe he didn’t like the Fair Grounds. Throw out those two duds, and Plus Que Parfait has a solid 2-1-2 in five starts. That includes a second and a third at Churchill Downs.

Why he won’t: The last two winners of the UAE Derby – Thunder Snow in 2017 and Mendelssohn in 2018 – finished last in the Kentucky Derby. Even trainer Brendan Walsh admitted the travel to and from Dubai takes a toll on horses.

DERBY DRAW: Check out the Kentucky Derby 2019 post position draw, jockeys, odds

Roadster

Why he can win: There was a time last summer that trainer Bob Baffert believed Roadster was the best 2-year-old in his barn. Surgery fixed the breathing issue that was discovered after his only loss, and the two victories this year at Santa Anita have showed promise.

Why he won’t: He doesn’t have enough experience, and he lost Hall of Fame jockey Mike Smith to Omaha Beach. The Santa Anita Derby set up perfectly, with the early leaders wearing down each other and Roadster picking up the pieces.

Read this: Bob Baffert is a great trainer, but betting on his horses is a 'losing proposition'

By My Standards

Why he can win: He’s been in the money in all five career starts, and by all accounts he’s been as impressive as any horse during workouts at Churchill over the past couple of weeks.

Why he won’t: The “wise-guy” horse never actually wins the Derby, and he seems to have gained that status. There are big questions about his pedigree and ability to get the 1 ¼-mile distance.

More: The definitive (and totally arbitrary) list of best Derby horse names

Maximum Security

Why he can win: He’s the only undefeated horse in the field and really hasn’t been challenged in any of his four races, the closest margin being 3 ½ lengths in the Florida Derby. As oddsmaker Mike Battaglia said, it’s possible this horse is a “freak.”

Why he won’t: His career debut was in a $16,000 claiming race, and trainer Jason Servis hasn’t hid the fact that Maximum Secruity wasn’t exactly a standout horse early in his career. He got away with an easy lead in the Florida Derby, and that won’t happen in the Run for the Roses.

Game Winner

Why he can win: He still might be the most talented horse in the field, as he enjoyed a dominant 2-year-old campaign that was capped by a victory in the Breeders’ Cup Juvenile at Churchill. Perhaps jockey Joel Rosario has learned a thing or two from his two defeats earlier this year.

Why he won’t: Close losses to Omaha Beach in the Rebel and to Roadster in the Santa Anita Derby are nothing to be ashamed of, but it’s possible Game Winner has a lost a step since last year. Do you trust a horse in the Derby who hasn’t won a race since November?

Kentucky Derby Media Poll: Bob Baffert has top 3 horses

Code of Honor

Why he can win: Trainer Shug McGaughey doesn’t show up at the Derby unless he thinks he has a solid chance to win, and he hasn’t had a Derby horse since Orb’s victory in 2013. Sunday’s speedy workout (four furlongs in 46.80 seconds) showed promise that Code of Honor could be closer to the pace than he’s been in recent races.

Why he won’t: His career-best Brisnet Speed Figure of 95 is a cut below the best horses in this field, and there are concerns that he’s just not fast enough to be there at the end.

SCRATCHED: Haikal

More: Haikal scratched from Kentucky Derby with abscess on left front hoof

Improbable

Why he can win: He has a win at Churchill and did it in impressive fashion, taking the Street Sense by 7 ¼ lengths on Breeders’ Cup weekend. He came straight to Churchill after the Arkansas Derby and seems to love the track.

Why he won’t: The ownership group of WinStar Farm, China Horse Club and Starlight Racing won last year’s Derby with Justify. The last owner to win back-to-back Derby was Penny Chenery and her Meadow Stable with Riva Ridge (1972) and Secretariat (1973).

War of Will

Why he can win: He had won three straight races and was considered a leading Derby contender before suffering a patella muscle injury during the Louisiana Derby and finishing ninth. Trainer Mark Casse is due some Derby luck after top contender Classic Empire was jostled early and finished fourth two years ago.

Why he won’t: No matter the excuse, it’s hard to imagine the ninth-place finisher from the Louisiana Derby coming back to win the Kentucky Derby. His speed figures would need to take a big jump to compete with the best in this field.

Long Range Toddy

Why he can win: He showed what’s he’s capable of in the Rebel, rallying to beat Improbable by a neck and securing his spot in the Kentucky Derby.

Why he won’t: Granted he was on a sloppy track, but his 83 Brisnet Speed Figure in the Arkansas Derby is the lowest last-race number of any horse in the Kentucky Derby field.

Tax

Why he can win: He’s the only horse in the field to have Brisnet Speed Figures over 100 in his last three races. And his pedigree – by Arch out of the Giant’s Causeway mare Toll – suggests the 1 ¼-mile Derby distance won’t be a problem.

Why he won’t: He had every chance in the world to beat Tacitus in the Wood Memorial and just couldn’t get it done. The water will be even deeper in the Kentucky Derby.

Cutting Humor

Why he can win: If you’re into the final-fractions theory, this is your horse. In winning the Sunland Derby, his times for the final furlong and final three furlongs were the fastest of any horse in the Kentucky Derby field.

Why he won’t: Mine That Bird is the only winner of the Sunland Derby to win the Kentucky Derby and did so at 50-1 odds. Cutting Humor may be just as big of a long shot.

Win Win Win

Why he can win: Sunday’s workout at Churchill, in which he chased down Tacitus and Country House down the stretch, was impressive. He’s never finished out of the money (3-2-1) in six career starts.

Why he won’t: He’s a closer, and there likely won’t be a hot pace in this Derby.

Check out: Trainers fight long odds to break into an exclusive club: the Kentucky Derby

Country House

Why he can win: He may well be in 20th place entering the first turn, but maybe everybody will tire in front of him and jockey Flavien Prat can work out the perfect trip down the stretch.

Why he won’t: There doesn’t appear to be a lot of early speed in this race, which doesn’t set up well for a horse like Country House who likes to come from way off the pace. With just one career victory, it’s hard to make much of a case for him.

Gray Magician

Why he can win: He’s got some early speed, and his best chance may be to pull a War Emblem and lead from start to finish.

Why he won’t: UAE Derby winners don’t win the Kentucky Derby, and UAE Derby runners-up certainly don’t.

Spinoff

Why he can win: He’s finished in the money in all of his races, and it’s dangerous to simply throw out a Todd Pletcher trainee. He figures to be near the front early and could have something left in the tank if the early fractions aren’t too fast.

Why he won’t: He only has four career starts, and he lost Hall of Fame jockey John Velazquez, who chose to ride Code of Honor instead. Manny Franco will have the mount in the Derby.

Master Fencer

Why he can win: Because you believe in miracles?

Why he won’t: He’s the first horse to qualify via the Japan Road to the Kentucky Derby. Only four horses foaled outside of the United State have won the Derby, the last being Sunny’s Halo (Canada) in 1983.

Jason Frakes: 502-582-4046; jfrakes@courier-journal.com; Twitter: @KentuckyDerbyCJ. Support strong local journalism by subscribing today: www.courier-journal.com/jasonf.
